data.text: Semantics: What Is the Difference between Bikepacking and Bike Touring?
Probably arguing semantics but; what in your opinion is the difference between bike-packing and touring?
Semantics
data.author: Brian Halley

data.text: Bikepacking is off road. Touring is on paved roads. You bikepack the GDMBR. You tour the Natchez Trace.
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: My opinion is touring is a longer trip with more stuff.
data.author: Eric Palazolo

data.text: None... No difference.
data.author: Robin Brodsky

data.text: Based on the official definitions, they‚Äôre very different. Bikepacking = off road, touring = on road.
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: I do pavement and gravel road link ups in the California Sierras. I carry gear for the long haul so I still use panniers
data.author: Darin Dunn

data.text: the name
data.author: Graham Pollitt

data.text: Bikepacking people use frame bags, fork bags, and seat bags (not panniers). They are a skinnier set-up to ride more on trails than roads. They look cooler üòé but don‚Äôt carry as much stuff!
data.author: Susie AndDarren Hamm

data.text: Nor do they carry it as well. Panniers can be organized so that you don‚Äôt have to dig through everything to get what you want. Bikepacking bags, with their weird shapes, are packed with items where they fit and may end up with, for example, cooking gear in several different bags. It makes using them more difficult when you have to unpack most of your gear just to get to your stove.
data.author: Stuart Black

data.text: Bikepacking bags attach directly to the bike frame and generally do not hold large amounts of gear, touring bags require racks and can often be fairly large. How you use them is up to you though bikepacking bags are usually more sensible on rougher off road tours especially where narrow single track may be encountered and where panniers would be an obstruction.
data.author: Timothy Dale

data.text: he didn't ask about the type of bags, he asked what the terms meant. and they mean the same thing. as for touring bags being an obstruction - if your feet and handlebars(!) can make it past, your bags will too. I've never seen a situation where it's too narrow for bags. there's a disadvantage to frame bags on technical terrain: the higher center of gravity.
data.author: Timm Sima

data.text: nothing more to do today?
data.author: Timothy Dale

data.text: it‚Äôs not my post/question. And I understood the question perfectly and answered it well. As for panniers not being obtrusive I would love to see you on technical single track with panniers. As for the terms it would be an incomplete answer if the types of bags was not explained. You sir are the jerk.
data.author: Timothy Dale

data.text: if I had known you'd get butthurt each time a person offers insight, I'd have refrained from bruising your ego. sorry pal, didn't mean to do that. I'll try to be as gentle as possible for you in the future.
data.author: Timm Sima

data.text: you offered no insight whatsoever. I don‚Äôt know what the Q factor is on your bikes but my panniers are wider than mine and most bikes I‚Äôve seen.
data.author: Timothy Dale

data.text: Actually....he did NOT ask about the terms.....he asked for anybody's OPINION of what the DIFFERENCE between the two types of cycling is. I'm SURE there is a difference....as "touring" is much, much older than "bike packing". I thought Timothy Dale's explanation was articulate, and he explained what the difference TO HIM, quite well. I personally don't really do either....so I appreciated the explanation. It might be correct....it might not be accurate at all. But if YOU have an opinion on the difference between the two types of cycling....then I will (might) listen to that!
data.author: Dale Richer

data.text: Bike packing sounds cooler other than that no difference mix of terrains, carrying bags how ever you try and dress it up its the same prove me wrong üòÄ
data.author: Mark Holland

data.text: Ever tried to do rugged roads with panniers? I have back before bikepacking bags became available. The biggest problem with panniers off-road is that they have a tendency not to stay attached to the bike. Fast, bumpy downhills are often interrupted with a hike down the hill to retrieve a bag that has flown off. For a while, it was better to ‚Äúbikepack‚Äù with a trailer but those have their own problems. Bikepacking bags are excellent for off-road touring. They aren‚Äôt perfect‚Ä¶too many different sizes and shapes, difficult to pack efficiently, load is carried to high, etc‚Ä¶but they ARE better on rugged terrain. Great for a weekend to a week of touring the backcountry. ‚Ä¶But if the touring is mostly road and for long enough that I need to laundry (about every 4 days), I‚Äôd use panniers over bikepacking bags any day.
data.author: Stuart Black

data.text: no one said bumpy roads but yes I have throw a bungee around and problem solved üòâ
data.author: Mark Holland

data.text: That‚Äôs the difference between touring and bikepacking‚Ä¶bumpy, rugged, rocky roads where road bikes don‚Äôt perform very well. I‚Äôm also not in the habit of carrying 3 foot long bungees, much less 4 of them‚Ä¶which is what would be needed to keep the pannier on.
data.author: Stuart Black

data.text: Modern bikepacking gear is better for rough travel. I never worry about bags coming loose at 30mph over rocks, ruts, and washboard.
data.author: Stuart Black

data.text: , Never had ortlieb hooks come off as they lock all the way around the bar. Saying that, have ridden gravel roads and smooth tracks only.
data.author: Aaron Davis

data.text: yes, ive met hundreds of people who've toured from europe to signapore on roads that bikepackers think has too much for panniers. In my opnion there is no difference in the two terms, except for what rules people build on their own minds.
data.author: Paul Hamon

data.text: Modern bags are a bit better but they still bounce a lot and the hooks can break. I‚Äôd prefer using panniers but for off-road, rugged travel (aka ‚Äúbikepacking‚Äù), bikepacking bags do work better. Smooth road, smooth gravel (think C&O/GAP), or extended travel, panniers are my choice.
data.author: Stuart Black

data.text: Bike Touring for me implies camping
data.author: Christopher √òrr

data.text: I always figured it was more implied in bikepacking (I assume the word came after backpacking). Also, the realm of 'touring' in my mind includes 'credit card touring' where you ride only slightly heavier than your weekend club ride from hotel to hotel.
data.author: Braden Graham

data.text: Marketing
data.author: Simon Leach

data.text: It sounds like splitting hairs, but it's useful to separate offroad 'bikepacking' and pavement 'touring', especially when discussing equipment, since such a wide variety exists.
data.author: Braden Graham

data.text: touring is definitely done off-pavement and bikepacking often includes pavement
data.author: Greg Gautreaux

data.text: of course, there is overlap, but if you ask for a bikepacking bike and get a bike with 3"+ offroad tires, then go do your cross country pavement ride (or ask for a touring bike, get a bike with 32mm slicks, big wide panniers, and little or no suspension, and do a ride in the mountains), you're going to have a rough time. Splitting the terminology for such purposes (then rejoining it simply to discuss long distance bike riding) is useful.
data.author: Braden Graham

data.text: think you got it backwards.
data.author: Bill Dove

data.text: Touring use to be on pavement then more off road became popular now many think bikepacking sounds cooler so most want to be called such. The equipment varies between the to ends of the spectrum but there is a lot of common ground. I don't ride predominately pavement on mountain bike tires and I don't bikepack on road tires.
data.author: Bill Dove

data.text: you‚Äôve got them reversed
data.author: Julie Rossall

data.text: no. They have overlap. Unless you added an ‚Äúexclusively‚Äù that I didn‚Äôt write. Great Divide bike packing race? Tires chosen for low rolling resistance on pavement *and* grippiness off-road. Likewise touring can take you off pavement. Not all off-pavement riding is technical single track. I assure you I can take a touring rig from DC to Pittsburgh via the C&O & GAP trails.

data.text: Bike-packing is easier to spell!üòÄ

data.text: I always thought bike packing meant less stuff and shorter distances, while bike touring meant the opposite. Guess I was wrong then. Thanks for info.
data.author: Martin Slovic

data.text: still sounds accurate, with a daily distance of pavement generally being longer than one on dirt, and pannier setups generally carrying more than a frame bag setup.
data.author: Braden Graham

data.text: more to do with terrain and/or daily distance than shorter distance on tours. I've spent five months off road touring with a bikepacking setup. Total weight attached to the bike was 14kg. That's about the same as four empty panniers and two racks.
data.author: David Butterly

data.text: no you're not wrong.
data.author: Paul Hamon

data.text: Bike packing is backpacking on a bike. I.e, you go to places that you might otherwise hike. Bike touring is more like hitch hiking without having to stick out your thumb.
data.author: Ben Beardmore

data.text: Also bike touring may be visiting places of interest such as museums, N.Trust properties, Botanic Gardens, churches, English Heritage places etc many of which have tea rooms.
data.author: Christine Roche

data.text: That's how I see Bike packing too. Very lightweight and more remote. I think some people use the term bikepacking for touring as it sounds tougher/sexier.

data.text: Air resistance and terrain adaptations.
data.author: Stephen Perry

data.text: I suppose for me the main difference is where you sleep, either camping (bike camping, not packing) or at BnBs/ hotels.

data.text: Not bike camping or hike camping but for some of us it is backpacking and bikepacking.

data.text: whatever
data.author: Eric Palladini

data.text: I guess you could argue a difference... Insofar as if I was heading out for a 10 miler overnight, I'd not tell people I was off touring. I suppose a tour implies just that - exploration of multiple places over multiple days / weeks. Bikepacking could also cover that... But I wouldn't use 'tour' to explain a shortish ride with the bike kitted out for an overnighter or two.
data.author: Dee Ball

data.text: , Vote 1 for best explanation. Tied to the duration of the event and number of different locations. I.e. I am going on a trip to Europe or a tour of Europe. The latter implies a lot longer duration and far more extensive number of places visited.
data.author: Aaron Davis

data.text: Bike-packing all cargo is streamlined on the bike. Bike packing‚Ä¶ there‚Äôs panniers involved. It there‚Äôs a nusance in distance and style.

data.text: I think you might like to reread your comment.

data.text: Touring, racks and panniers. Bikepacking, frame bags, fork bags, seatpack. Touring mainly tarmac or reasonably smooth tracks. Bikepacking, off-road rough stuff.

data.author: Matthew James

data.text: so if there are rear racks with panniers, a front bike bag and bag in the frame, a ride that goes both off-road and on the roads (there's a combination going across Michigan as I did last year), is that bikepacking or touring? Not arguing, not doubting you, just curious.
data.author: Elisha Hall

data.text: Whatever you like, it really doesn't matter. Originally if you went on a trip on a bike over multiple days it was cycle touring, regardless of how or what you carried. Then quite recently someone invented the term bikepacking, along with term gravel bike, and with those came different ways of carrying stuff, and slightly different bikes. It is still all touring really, just "bikepacking" and "gravel bikes" are trendier!
data.author: Robin Symonds

data.text: Ha! Agreed. I struggle with the terms, so I use them interchangeably. It doesn't seem as though there is much, if any difference. I appreciated your post, though, because you had specifics. Thank you for humoring me.

data.text: Heading out on an adventure, one with a backpack off the beaten path The other a station wagon

data.text: Who cares, this idea of dividing cyclists and arguing amongst ourselves is out of hand. This isn't a black and white issue, there is the ability to mix all shades of Grey.
data.author: Alex Helling

data.text: It isn't necessarily divisive, just nuanced. Think of different types of kayaking (ocean vs river are generally different boats); target shooting (clay targets vs long distance target on a range, different guns, similar activity), or even other disciplines of biking (Downhill and XC racing both use full squish bikes but they are different and you wouldn't want to take one bike on the other's course).

data.author: Ignacio Duran

data.text: There used to be more distinction between what people meant. "Bikepacking": No front or rear racks, bags in the frame and attached to the bike directly, and "Touring" uses front and rear racks to attach the bikes. However, this ignores the long tradition of using large seat bags and handlebar bags like those made by Caradice, and the use of frame bags in touring (They were offered by several bike bag manufacturers in the 70s and early 80s.). The difference has faded with bikepacking using larger and larger bags that require some sort of rod for support (But, it can't be a rack!) and using small packs on cages on the forks (But, they aren't racks!), or even Tailfin's bikepacking rear rack. To me Bikepacking is looking more like what used to be called "adventure touring". Speaking of which, there are plenty of world bike tourists that ride off-road into extremely remote areas. To me it is almost all marketing, but I am "lumper" rather than a "splitter".
data.author: Mike Kroeger

data.text: Although, when I first heard of bikepacking, I noticed a lot of bikepackers wore backpacks, whereas tourist didn't. I thought that was the distinction for quite awhile.
data.author: Mike Kroeger

data.text: Touring is on the road and bikepacking is off road

data.text: So many comments saying bags on bike is bikepacking and on a pannier touring. My last trip I had handlebar bag, frame bag, top bar bag and panniers...help which group do I belong in??? I can't identify!!! To make it even more confusing I even road on tarmac and rough stuff, is their even a group for riders that identify this way!?
data.author: Richard Record

data.text: #metoo üòÜ
data.author: John Axson

data.text: , I am sorry but you don‚Äôt conform to any recognised group so you will have to stand outside on your own! You can only have friends by being in one group or the other and the bikepacking group is the new and cooler group that everyone wants to be in. The good news is that you can buy you way in. You don‚Äôt have to have actually gone on a single overnight ride to be in the group. It is expensive though to join. All you have to do is go out and buy an expensive but cool looking mongrel bike (Road bike look, but with wider MTB esk tyres), buy lots of expensive bags that are super small but with rugged brand names and lots of for purpose gear including tents that have only half of what you really need but have a super low kg number on it and then (and this is the important step), lay out the gear in the shape of a perfect square and take a photo of it, take a photo of the said bike e with bags on it and then post your pics plus you intent to go bikepacking on Insta and your done! You will be welcomed in to the group arms wide open. You don‚Äôt even have to have actually gone anywhere over night! If you want to be a higher status member, it is not about the trips that you have done (you can just talk about the ones your gunna do), you just need to ensure your fork and frames have lots of braze on points, has no suspension and is made of steel. Oh, and grow a beard. If you are forced to go overnight, you could always just stay in a hotel (this is accepted) or keep the nights done to one or two at the most. Now if you want to join the touring group, you are going to have to actually go on some decent tours in exotic locations or at least travelling across countries and prove yourself before you are welcomed in. And if/when you are, don‚Äôt expect recognition from those outside of the group. It is just not as Insta friendly and the gear manufactures don‚Äôt make money out of you as the panniers last 20years and you don‚Äôt need special over priced tents that you have to carry on your handlebars with your ultralight sleeping bag in a gear holder on you forks!

data.text: I think bike packing is more in line with how we prefer to kit ourselves out and travel in the Backpackerrs Club, whereas touring has changed radically since the YHA started closing hostels. It used to be what you could squeeze into a long flap Carradice, for a week or so. I have equipped myself for touring with 4 panniers and a mixture of hiking and cycling gear, I don't intend to fill the 4 bags, just to distribute the gear I plan to take so that the bike is balanced

data.author: Gary Moonan

data.text: his does make me chuckle - if you walk long distance paths even on the same in the UK you will usually meet a mixture of approaches - walking, staying in B and Bs and hostels carrying your gear, on organised routes you may find people with day packs having their luggage transported, backpackers carrying camping gear etc. You are all walkers. You go to the Alps and things get more technical, you might be going between staying in huts but carrying technical gear for glacier crossings, perhaps via ferrata, you might be doing easy walks and camping, you might be doing serious climbing and bivying you'll still hear it described as walking or moutaineering.
data.author: Skogar Iceland

data.text: I found the answer when I didn't want to spend more money on a touring (steel) bike and discovered bike packing , the philosophy was to travel as light as possible on your normal road bike using a seat and handle bar bags.
data.author: Mark Sippings

data.text: About $1000... ü§£
data.author: Russ Norman

data.text: There is no difference but the marketing folks would like to tell you otherwise.
data.author: Nick Mallett

data.text: To me back packing, cycle touring, cycle camping are all points on the same and the approach selected will depend on personal preference / suitability / what gear you have. If you are going from place to place you are touring, the kit and the set up will depend on whether you are stopping at B and Bs etc, camping, bivying, sleeping in bus shelters or similar, and the level of luxury of any camping is self selected. Similarly you are going to pick a suitable bike for the terrain you think you are most likely to be cycling on. Bike packing isn't new - people have been travelling about by bicycle since bicycles were invented. I would argue that one of the early bikepackers of note was probably Thomas Stevens who went round the world on his penny farthing and packed his handlebar bag with socks, a spare shirt, a raincoat that doubled as tent and bedroll, and a pocket revolver. A bikepacking kit list to be proud of. But was he a really a bike packer? Would he have taken panniers containing some clean underwear and maybe a bar of soap had they been available to him and was he limited just by what he could get in that handlebar bag? He probably mostly ravelled on roads but I suspect they were not that great so was he a cycle tourer or a bike packer and does it matter? My argument is that providing you are having fun it doesn't really matter what you call it. Perhaps the old term "adventure cyclist" should stage a comeback?
data.author: Skogar Iceland

data.text: Bike packing is mostly off road. Bike touring is mostly on the road. How you pack your bike has no relevance to it being touring or packing.

data.text: My tent is not too small for a folded Brompton and the Brompton T-bag and rackpack come off easily. Bikepacking for me is a variation of backpacking.
data.author: Christine Roche

data.text: My longer answer: You need to pick a group to be in. The bikepacking group is the new and cooler group that everyone wants to be in. The good news is that you can buy you way in. You don‚Äôt have to have actually gone on a single overnight ride to be in the group. It is expensive though to join. All you have to do is go out and buy an expensive but cool looking mongrel bike (Road bike look, but with wider MTB esk tyres), buy lots of expensive bags that are super small but with rugged brand names and lots of for purpose gear including tents that have only half of what you really need but have a super low kg number on it and then (and this is the important step), lay out the gear in the shape of a perfect square and take a photo of it, take a photo of the said bike e with bags on it and then post your pics plus you intent to go bikepacking on Insta and your done! You will be welcomed in to the group arms wide open. You don‚Äôt even have to have actually gone anywhere over night! If you want to be a higher status member, it is not about the trips that you have done (you can just talk about the ones your gunna do), you just need to ensure your fork and frames have lots of braze on points, has no suspension and is made of steel. Oh, and grow a beard. If you are forced to go overnight, you could always just stay in a hotel (this is accepted) or keep the nights done to one or two at the most. Now if you want to join the touring group, you are going to have to actually go on some decent tours in exotic locations or at least travelling across countries and prove yourself before you are welcomed in. And if/when you are, don‚Äôt expect recognition from those outside of the group. It is just not as Insta friendly and the gear manufactures don‚Äôt make money out of you as the panniers last 20years and you don‚Äôt need special over priced tents that you have to carry on your handlebars with your ultralight sleeping bag in a gear holder on you forks! So it is really a choice. Do you want to look adventurous and cool to your non-bike friends and followers on Insta or not? üòâ

data.author: MaryKay Simoni

data.text: Mix e-bikes into the question and you'll have a full blown civil war! That said, aside from "what bike & bags look like" and "what surface is preferred" I find the most important differentiator to actually be the length of the trip / degree of autonomy: if you go more than a couple of days and want to travel independently from infrastructure, your choice will be reduced to a sturdy bike with racks and panniers. 'Touring' originates from French and relates to words like 'promenade' or 'stroll'. And that's how I like to look at it: for me, touring isn't about maximizing distance, speed, or minimizing weight, but about what we explore & experience along the journey.
data.author: Thomas Arson

data.text: Another thing to consider: most bikes sold today don't have the brazings needed to bolt on panniers. Bikepacking allows for carrying any luggage at all, without investing into a dedicated bike and/or racks. Half way decent racks alone can run you $250, frames made to carry those racks and the associated weight with dignity are heavy and easily cost you another $1000. Add to that $300-400 worth of Ortlieb bags and you can see why bike packing seems attractive at first glance.
data.author: Thomas Arson

data.text: new term for the same thing really. if you're talking about bags, the terms is frame-fit versus panier bags. some might nuance touring in the wilderness versus on roads maybe? but it's really the same thing.
data.author: Timm Sima

data.text: Touring: taking a sensible amount of gear and staying wherever takes your fancy; campsite, hotel, hostel, friends etc. Bikepacking: taking less than the minimalist amount of gear, experiencing excessive discomfort, getting attacked by insects and having to take a dump behind a tree. (I like my comforts.)
data.author: David Farnsworth

data.text: One answer I haven't seen is the bike (I haven't looked too far through all the answers). Touring bikes tend to be more robust to enable greater load management (panniers), whereas bikepacking bikes can be more lightweight to enable speedier and faster travels. Both bikes can swap roles, yet my cross/gravel bike at 8kg with bikepacking bags will be lot faster on and off road, than my 13kg tour bike. While my cross bike can't handle panniers as well as the flexible aluminium frame isn't happy with the load. As to semantics. I don't believe I want to survive a Scottish summer with bikepacking equipment - too many bugs (midges) and it'll be difficult carrying a tent. Similarly a winter as I can't carry enough warmth. Also getting truely off-road mean carrying food & water, and that becomes difficult. Maybe I like my comforts... Still going to try sometime.
data.author: David Sykes

data.text: Theyre the same in my opinion
data.author: George Homer

data.text: In my opinion the difference is the same as between adventure biking and bicycle touring in the motorcycle section. Heavier bikes on tarmac instead of lighter bikes in terrain.
data.author: Anette Sidest√•l

data.text: Perhaps the only descriptions I've read to separate the two that make sense is that bike-packing also involves going off-road, touring is sticking to roads (and civilized paths). The types of bags and attachments is immaterial imo, you need to carry your own gear to be self-sufficient whatever you're doing. Amount of gear will depend on many factors like which countries you plan to visit, time of year, where you'll sleep overnight, how much luxury you want. Its all a very personal experience so ultimately you probably called it right from the start - it's semantics.

data.text: The technical difference is how and what bags attach to the bike. The real difference is in the marketing and sucking cyclists into thinking they need something newer, different, better, etc. Ride what you have how you want!
data.author: Mike Samsen

data.text: The amount of gear you take
data.author: KerryJane Voth

data.text: It is clear is a lot of people some very different ideas, and many use the terms bike-packing and touring interchangeably to a degree, though mostly with the assumption bike-packing is a bit lighter. Listening to all this, i am coming to the conclusion that bike packing fills the gap between touring with a full load and ultra racing. One thing i will say when you look across countries , is that with bike packing the choice of equipment is based on the train and the environment from an MTB through gravel bikes to endurance racing bikes. and a whole load of hybrids, ebikes and wha can say what added in for luck.
data.author: Julian Young

data.text: Touring is the trip, and bike packing is the destination.
data.author: Dan Rykiel

data.text: Touring is a longer event..a week, a month longer..Bike Packing is normally shorter. Touring uses panniers front and back...Bike packing is a lot less gear.
data.author: Martin Fano

data.text: Agree that the terms are interchangeable. Cycle Touring was what we did in 1980's when we cycled lots of rough dirt roads all over Australia and South America. We had side panniers on the front wheel, side panniers on the rear and a handlebar bag. We used a Kangaroo Bag made in the USA and attached using velcro. We never took those off at night as they were so painful to put back on tightly enough. Use Ortleib now and they work pretty well still. Still love the dirt rough stuff and a mix of the not. Have gear train that pedals at 50km/hr and at 4km/hr. So what you do and what you call it is upto you! Make sure you love it!!!
data.author: Angela Mosley

data.text: Riding your bike vs pushing your bike.

data.author: David Huckins

data.text: I compare them with a backpacker and a suitcase tourist. One is less bulkier, more agile and in many ways faster. No need check in bags, can hop on anything or walk through any terrains if need be. But cannot carry a lot due to lack of space. The suitcase tourist has a bit more luxuries, more bulkier means more space to carry more and heavier in weight. Not so quick, not so agile and needs more patience. Harsh terrains are not practical. I don‚Äôt think one is better than the other. It‚Äôs subjective to the traveler‚Äôs preferred style of travel. More importantly, both get to travel‚Ä¶ ‚úåÔ∏è
data.author: Nurul Asyiken

data.text: In my opinion bikepacking is more remote travel with more of a ultralight setup, where touring is more a vacation but your travel mode is a bike. I‚Äôve tried both but personally prefer the little luxuries that come with touring, but bikepacking can bring you to more remote areas. Comes down to personal preferences I guess!
